person_635.name: DanielRutherford
person_635.description: Scottish physician, chemist, and botanist who isolated nitrogen in 1772.

person_224.name: Carl WilhelmScheele
person_224.description: Swedish-German pharmaceutical chemist. One of the discoverers of what would later be called oxygen (1771) as well as other chemical elements including what Davy renamed chlorine.

person_026.name: HenryCavendish
person_026.description: A central figure in English natural philosophy and chemistry, among other research he determined the density of the earth and discovered what would later be named hydrogen. He was one of the people who helped appoint Davy to the Royal Institution. Following his death in 1810 Davy delivered a widely-quoted eulogy on Cavendish and later arranged for some of his apparatus to be transferred to the Royal Institution. FRSL.

person_012.name: Joseph LouisGay-Lussac
person_012.description: French chemist and physicist, known mostly for his discovery that water is made of two parts hydrogen and one part oxygen by volume (with Alexander von Humboldt), for two laws related to gases, and for his work on alcohol-water mixtures. Became involved in controversies with Davy over various chemical discoveries. ForMemRSL.

person_349.name: Jöns JacobBerzelius
person_349.description: Swedish chemist. He discovered the chemical elements cerium and selenium, and was the first to isolate silicon, thorium, titanium, and zirconium. A rival of Davy's whom he met a few times.

person_132.name: Martin afPontin
person_132.description: Swedish court physician. Worked with Berzelius on following up Davy's work in electro-chemistry.

person_133.name: Thomas JohannSeebeck
person_133.description: Born to wealthy German parents in what is now Estonia. Worked on the electro-magnetism before discovering thermo-electricity in 1822.

person_016.name: JosephPriestley
person_016.description: Unitarian and political radical forced into exile in Pennsylvania. As a natural philospher and chemist who retained belief in phlogiston, he discovered oxygen and nitrous oxide though not under those names. FRSL.

person_066.name: JohnDalton
person_066.description: Mancunian chemist and natural philosopher who lectured at the Royal Institution. He formulated a version of the atomic theory of matter much disliked by Davy. FRSL.

person_459.name: RamonLlull
person_459.description: Catalonian philosopher, theologian, poet, missionary, Christian apologist.

person_1054.name: Abū MūsāJābir ibn Ḥayyān
person_1054.description: the purported author of a large number of works in Arabic, often called the Jabirian corpus. His name is often latinized to Gebir or Geber.

person_702.name: EdwardKelley
person_702.description: English alchemist and associate of John Dee.

person_701.name: ThomasBrowne
person_701.description: Seventeenth-century writer, especially on the natural world.

person_033.name: Torbern OlafBergman
person_033.description: Swedish chemist and mineralogist. At some point Davy acquired a set of letters from Bergman to Franz Schwediaur written in the 1780s which are retained in the Royal Institution (RI MS HD/27/A). ForMemRSL.

person_165.name: WilliamHiggins
person_165.description: Nephew of Bryan Higgins. Professor of Chemistry at the Dublin Society where he proposed a theory of chemical atomism. Met Davy in London who supported Higgins's claim to the atomic theory over that of John Dalton. FRSL.

person_461.name: Johannes JacobWecker
person_461.description: Swiss physician and philosopher, best known for his work in the history of alchemy.

person_203.name: Jean-BaptisteBiot
person_203.description: French mathematician, physicist and astronomer; Professor of Physics at the Collège de France. ForMemRSL.

person_202.name: Dominique François JeanArago
person_202.description: French mathematician, physicist, astronomer and political liberal. Davy presented him with the Copley Medal in 1825. ForMemRSL.

person_036.name: IsaacNewton
person_036.description: Prominent English natural philosopher and mathematician greatly admired by Davy who once under the influence of several litres of nitrous oxide wrote in his notebook 'Davy & Newton' in one inch letters. FRSL.

person_240.name: ErasmusDarwin
person_240.description: Physician and natural philosopher who was member of the Lunar Society and friend of Priestley and Watt; also a correspondent with Beddoes. FRSL.

place_851.name: St Stephen-in-Brannel
place_851.description: St Stephen-in-Brannel is a civil parish and village in mid Cornwall.

place_021.name: Cornwall
place_021.description: Cornwall is a county in south-west England, birthplace of Humphry Davy.

place_370.name: Rowley Hills
place_370.description: A range of hills in the West Midlands, England.

place_853.name: Banská Štiavnica
place_853.description: Banská Štiavnica is a town in central Slovakia, in the middle of an immense caldera created by the collapse of an ancient volcano.

place_1027.name: Hungary
place_1027.description: a landlocked country in Central Europe. Its capital, Budapest, is bisected by the Danube River.

place_177.name: Andes
place_177.description: Mountain range in western South America.
